sets.title: RCVS Farm Animal Mock Exam – 50 MCQs

questions.stem: A dairy herd reports 4 abortions in 60 cows over 3 weeks. Annual abortion rate is 4%. Most appropriate interpretation?

options.text: Below intervention threshold – no action required
Cluster suggests infectious cause despite annual rate

questions.explanationShort: A cluster in a short time suggests infectious abortion even if annual rate is under 5%.
questions.explanationLong: RCVS often tests that temporal clustering (several abortions in weeks) is suspicious for infectious causes and should trigger investigation, even when the annual percentage looks ‘acceptable’.

questions.stem: Which finding most strongly suggests infectious rather than non-infectious abortion?
questions.explanationShort: Clustering in time is a classic infectious red flag.
questions.explanationLong: A tight cluster suggests an infectious process (e.g., BVD/IBR/lepto etc.). Non-infectious causes are often sporadic unless there’s a clear shared exposure.

questions.stem: Most useful material to increase diagnostic yield in abortion investigation:
questions.explanationShort: Fetus + placenta/membranes gives the best chance of diagnosis.
questions.explanationLong: Many pathogens and lesions are in placenta. Submitting fetus and membranes improves lab yield substantially.

questions.stem: Which infection commonly causes abortion without clinical signs?
questions.explanationShort: BVD can cause reproductive loss with minimal maternal signs.
questions.explanationLong: BVD infections can be clinically silent in the dam yet cause embryonic loss, abortion, congenital defects, or PI calves depending on timing.

questions.stem: Statutory abortion investigation in UK is focused on:
questions.explanationShort: Bovine abortions are reported primarily for brucellosis surveillance.
questions.explanationLong: In the UK, abortion reporting is especially linked to statutory brucellosis investigation (historically important, high consequence).

questions.stem: Brucella abortus is most heavily shed in:
questions.explanationShort: Highest load is in abortion material and uterine discharges.
questions.explanationLong: Brucella is massively shed at abortion/calving via placenta, fluids, and uterine discharges—highly infectious to herd mates and people.

questions.stem: Following abortion due to brucellosis, cow will:

options.text: Often calve normally but continue shedding

questions.explanationShort: May calve normally later but remain infectious.
questions.explanationLong: A classic exam point: later pregnancies may look normal, but infected cattle may still shed around parturition.

questions.stem: In BVD, infection at 90 days gestation results in:
questions.explanationShort: Before ~110–120 days → immune tolerance → PI calf.
questions.explanationLong: Infection before fetal immune competence can produce persistently infected calves that shed virus lifelong (main reservoir).

questions.stem: Mucosal disease is fatal because:

options.text: Cytopathic strain superinfection in PI animal

questions.explanationShort: Occurs in PI animals when cytopathic virus is involved.
questions.explanationLong: Mucosal disease is essentially a catastrophic BVD syndrome in PI animals; it’s classically fatal.

questions.stem: The most effective BVD eradication strategy:

options.text: Identification and removal of PI animals

questions.explanationShort: Remove PI animals to stop ongoing transmission.
questions.explanationLong: Vaccination supports control but eradication requires identifying and removing PIs (main within-herd source).

questions.stem: Target % cows calving of mated in 9-week breeding period:
questions.explanationShort: A common KPI target is ≥95% calving of mated cows.
questions.explanationLong: Compact calving drives uniform calf crop and profitability. >5% barren/poor calving performance prompts investigation.

questions.stem: Cow must conceive within how many days postpartum to maintain 12-month calving interval?
questions.explanationShort: 82 days postpartum is the classic target for a 12-month interval.
questions.explanationLong: 365 days − 283 days gestation ≈ 82 days. This number comes up a lot in farm exam questions.

questions.stem: Most important factor affecting length of postpartum anoestrus:
questions.explanationShort: Suckling is the biggest driver of prolonged postpartum anoestrus.
questions.explanationLong: Multiple factors affect cyclicity, but suckling is classically the major one; low BCS also prolongs anoestrus.

questions.stem: Heifer should reach what % mature bodyweight before breeding?
questions.explanationShort: Target around 65% mature weight before breeding.
questions.explanationLong: Heifers at ~65% mature BW are more likely to have reached puberty/cycling. Underweight heifers have poorer conception and later calving.

questions.stem: >5% assisted calvings is associated with:
questions.explanationShort: High dystocia/assistance rates reduce fertility performance.
questions.explanationLong: Assisted calvings increase postpartum disease and delay return to cyclicity, reducing conception rates and compact calving performance.

questions.stem: Main cause of dystocia in beef herds:
questions.explanationShort: Most common cause is oversized calves (fetopelvic disproportion).
questions.explanationLong: Often linked to sire choice, heifer size, and nutrition. Prevention uses easy-calving genetics and appropriate heifer growth targets.

questions.stem: Optimal BCS at calving (beef cow):
questions.explanationShort: BCS 2.5–3 is generally optimal at calving.
questions.explanationLong: Too thin → poor fertility/long anoestrus; too fat → dystocia/metabolic issues and wasted feed costs.

questions.stem: Cows with BCS <2 at calving typically show:
questions.explanationShort: Low BCS delays return to cyclicity postpartum.
questions.explanationLong: Negative energy balance and poor body reserves prolong postpartum anoestrus and reduce conception rates.

questions.stem: Bull scrotal circumference target at 24 months:
questions.explanationShort: A common target is ~34 cm at 24 months.
questions.explanationLong: Scrotal circumference correlates with semen output and earlier puberty in female offspring. Targets vary slightly by breed.

questions.stem: Most likely cause of temporary testicular degeneration:
questions.explanationShort: Fever can temporarily damage spermatogenesis.
questions.explanationLong: Spermatogenesis is temperature sensitive. Fever/systemic illness can impair semen quality for weeks afterwards.

questions.stem: BRSV primarily affects:
questions.explanationShort: Commonest in young calves (often <6 months).
questions.explanationLong: BRSV is a major component of bovine respiratory disease in youngstock; adults can be affected but calves are typical.

questions.stem: Most characteristic lesion of BRSV:
questions.explanationShort: Diffuse interstitial pneumonia is typical.
questions.explanationLong: BRSV causes interstitial pneumonia with oedema/emphysema; secondary bacterial bronchopneumonia may complicate cases.

questions.stem: Most rapid and sensitive BRSV diagnostic:
questions.explanationShort: PCR is rapid and practical; culture is difficult.
questions.explanationLong: BRSV isolation is challenging; PCR detects viral nucleic acid quickly from respiratory samples.

questions.stem: Passively derived immunity in BRSV:
questions.explanationShort: Maternal antibodies mainly reduce severity.
questions.explanationLong: Passive immunity does not reliably prevent infection or shedding but can reduce clinical severity and mortality.

questions.stem: Case fatality rate in BRSV outbreaks may reach:
questions.explanationShort: Can be up to around 10–20% in severe outbreaks.
questions.explanationLong: Morbidity is often high; fatality varies with management, secondary infections, and timeliness of treatment.

questions.stem: Bluetongue is transmitted by:
questions.explanationShort: Vector-borne via Culicoides biting midges.
questions.explanationLong: Bluetongue epidemiology depends on midge distribution/activity; it’s not primarily spread by animal-to-animal direct contact.

questions.stem: Most important differential for Bluetongue:
questions.explanationShort: FMD is the key notifiable differential.
questions.explanationLong: BT can resemble FMD (oral lesions/lameness). FMD has major legal and outbreak implications, so it must be high on the differential list.

questions.stem: Vaccination against BTV-8 protects against:
questions.explanationShort: Bluetongue immunity is largely serotype-specific.
questions.explanationLong: Vaccines are targeted to serotypes; BTV-8 vaccination does not reliably protect against other serotypes.

questions.stem: Ruminal lactic acidosis results from:
questions.explanationShort: Carbohydrate overload → lactic acid production → pH crash.
questions.explanationLong: Sudden grain/concentrate ingestion shifts rumen flora, increases lactate, causes rumen stasis, dehydration, metabolic acidosis, endotoxaemia.

questions.stem: Early acidosis diarrhoea appears:
questions.explanationShort: Often delayed; commonly 12–24 hours after overload.
questions.explanationLong: Early signs may be dullness/ataxia/colic; diarrhoea is often absent initially then becomes profuse as rumen contents alter and gut motility changes.

questions.stem: Most important preventive strategy for acidosis:
questions.explanationShort: Adapt rumen gradually to higher starch diets.
questions.explanationLong: Gradual dietary transition with adequate fibre is the key preventive. Buffers can help but don’t replace correct feeding management.

questions.stem: Listeriosis is most commonly associated with:
questions.explanationShort: Poor silage preservation is the classic risk factor.
questions.explanationLong: Listeria monocytogenes proliferates in poorly fermented silage; outbreaks are linked to feeding such forage.

questions.stem: Classic neurological sign in listeriosis:
questions.explanationShort: Unilateral brainstem signs → circling to affected side.
questions.explanationLong: Brainstem encephalitis causes cranial nerve deficits (e.g., facial paralysis), head tilt, circling/leaning, depression.

questions.stem: Coccidiosis most common age group:
questions.explanationShort: Usually affects young lambs around 4–8 weeks.
questions.explanationLong: Young animals are most susceptible before acquired immunity develops; disease is promoted by crowding and contamination.

questions.stem: Coccidia oocysts are:
questions.explanationShort: Oocysts persist and resist many environmental stresses.
questions.explanationLong: Oocysts survive for long periods and resist many disinfectants; hygiene and reducing stocking density are key controls.

questions.stem: Highly sensitive test with negative result is useful to:
questions.explanationShort: SNOUT: Sensitive test Negative rules OUT disease.
questions.explanationLong: High sensitivity means few false negatives; a negative result makes the disease unlikely.

questions.stem: If prevalence decreases, PPV:
questions.explanationShort: Lower prevalence → more false positives proportionally → PPV drops.
questions.explanationLong: With fewer true cases, a positive test is less likely to be a true positive, reducing PPV.

questions.stem: If prevalence decreases, NPV:
questions.explanationShort: Lower prevalence → more true negatives → NPV rises.
questions.explanationLong: When disease is rare, negative results are more likely to be true negatives.

questions.stem: Sensitivity formula:
questions.explanationShort: Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN).
questions.explanationLong: Proportion of diseased animals correctly identified as positive.

questions.stem: Specificity formula:
questions.explanationShort: Specificity = TN / (TN + FP).
questions.explanationLong: Proportion of non-diseased animals correctly identified as negative.

questions.stem: Minimum withdrawal for meat under cascade:
questions.explanationShort: Statutory minimum meat withdrawal under cascade: 28 days.
questions.explanationLong: When prescribing under cascade in food animals, the vet must set an appropriate withdrawal, at least the statutory minimum (often quoted: 28 days meat).

questions.stem: Minimum withdrawal for milk under cascade:
questions.explanationShort: Statutory minimum milk withdrawal under cascade: 7 days.
questions.explanationLong: Under cascade, the vet must set withdrawal periods; commonly taught minimum for milk (and eggs) is 7 days.

questions.stem: Category 1 ABP includes:
questions.explanationShort: SRM is Category 1 (highest risk).
questions.explanationLong: Category 1 includes SRM and other high-risk materials (e.g., TSE-risk).

questions.stem: Category 2 ABP includes:
questions.explanationShort: Manure is Category 2 ABP.
questions.explanationLong: Category 2 includes manure and GI contents and other higher-risk ABPs that are not Category 1.

questions.stem: Category 3 ABP includes:
questions.explanationShort: Fluke-damaged liver is Category 3 (lowest risk).
questions.explanationLong: Category 3 includes parts from animals fit for slaughter but not for human consumption for local/non-systemic reasons (e.g., localized parasitic lesions).

questions.stem: POM-V medicines require:
questions.explanationShort: POM-V requires vet Rx + clinical assessment under care.
questions.explanationLong: POM-V medicines can only be prescribed by a veterinarian following clinical assessment of animals under their care.

questions.stem: POM-VPS may be prescribed by:
questions.explanationShort: POM-VPS can be prescribed by vet/pharmacist/SQP.
questions.explanationLong: POM-VPS medicines can be supplied by authorised prescribers including SQPs, depending on product class and regulations.

questions.stem: In prescribing cascade, first alternative step is:
questions.explanationShort: First: UK-authorised veterinary product for another species/condition.
questions.explanationLong: Cascade order matters: the first step is usually a UK-authorised veterinary medicine for another species or different indication.

questions.stem: Under cascade, vet must:
questions.explanationShort: Vet must set a withdrawal period (≥ statutory minimum).
questions.explanationLong: The prescriber is legally responsible for specifying an appropriate withdrawal period when using cascade in food-producing animals.

questions.stem: Bluetongue in UK is:
questions.explanationShort: Bluetongue is notifiable in the UK.
questions.explanationLong: It is vector-borne and controlled via surveillance/movement restrictions/vaccination strategies depending on policy.
